text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Minister Simeon Nyachae says last week's cabinet reshuffle in which he was 'demoted' from the Ministry of Agriculture to that of Land Reclamation does not bother him.
- Kenya Revenue Authority makes a major reshuffle affecting 78 middle and senior level management staff in the Customs and Excise department.
- Valentine Kodipo, the man who claims to be a witness to the killing in Kenya of tourist Julie Ward, appears to have gone missing in Denmark.
- A schoolgirl is murdered in a chilling human sacrifice ritual by a woman relative who wanted 'the spirits' to guarantee her own children's success in education.
- Veteran politician Paul Ngei wins his bankruptcy battle when the High Court discharges his case thus opening the door for the ex-minister's re-entry into politics.
- In two separate incidents, three policemen are shot dead by their colleagues on Monday.
- Five tourists and ten other travellers die on the spot when a bus they were travelling in overturns and rolls several times along the Lamu-Garsen road in North Eastern Kenya.
